medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Carpal tunnel syndrome. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Carpal tunnel syndrome. PROCEDURE: Endoscopic release of left transverse carpal ligament. ANESTHESIA: Monitored anesthesia care with regional anesthesia provided by surgeon. TOURNIQUET TIME: 12 minutes. OPERATIVE PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: With the patient under adequate monitored anesthesia, the left upper extremity was prepped and draped in a sterile manner. The arm was exsanguinated. The tourniquet was elevated at 290 mmHg. Construction lines were made on the left palm to identify the ring ray. A transverse incision was made in the palm between FCR and FCU, one finger breadth proximal to the interval between the glabrous skin of the palm and normal forearm skin. Blunt dissection exposed the antebrachial fascia. Hemostasis was obtained with bipolar cautery. A distal based window in the antebrachial fascia was then fashioned. Care was taken to protect the underlying contents. A synovial elevator was used to palpate the undersurface of the transverse carpal ligament, and synovium was elevated off this undersurface. Hamate sounds were then used to palpate the Hood of Hamate. The Agee Inside Job was then inserted into the proximal incision. The transverse carpal ligament was easily visualized through the portal. Using palmar pressure, transverse carpal ligament was held against the portal as the instrument was inserted down the transverse carpal ligament to the distal end. The distal end of the transverse carpal ligament was then identified in the window. The blade was then elevated, and the Agee Inside Job was withdrawn, dividing transverse carpal ligament under direct vision. After complete division of transverse carpal ligament, the Agee Inside Job was reinserted. Radial and ulnar edges of the transverse carpal ligament were identified and complete release was accomplished. One cc of Celestone was then introduced into the carpal tunnel and irrigated free. The wound was then closed with a running 3-0 Prolene subcuticular stitch. Steri-strips were applied and a sterile dressing was applied over the Steri-strips. The tourniquet was deflated. The patient was awakened from anesthesia and returned to the recovery room in satisfactory condition having tolerated the procedure well.
layman:
**Pre‑operative diagnosis:** Carpal tunnel syndrome.  
**Post‑operative diagnosis:** Carpal tunnel syndrome.  
**Procedure:** Endoscopic release of the left transverse carpal ligament.  
**Anesthesia:** Monitored anesthesia care with regional anesthesia given by the surgeon.  
**Tourniquet time:** 12 minutes.  

**Operative details:**  
With the patient under monitored anesthesia, the left arm was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. The arm was emptied of blood and a tourniquet was set to 290 mmHg. Lines were drawn on the left palm to locate the ring finger. A small horizontal cut was made in the palm between the two forearm muscles (FCR and FCU), just above the line where the palm skin meets the forearm skin. Gentle cutting exposed the outer layer of the forearm. Bleeding was stopped with a bipolar cautery device. A small opening was made in this outer layer, taking care to protect the tissues underneath. A synovial elevator was used to feel the underside of the transverse carpal ligament and lift the synovium off it. A hammer was used to feel the hamate bone. The Agee Inside Job instrument was then inserted through the incision. The transverse carpal ligament could be seen through the portal. By pressing from the palm side, the ligament was held against the portal while the instrument was moved down the ligament to its far end. The far end of the ligament was found in the opening. The blade was lifted, and the instrument was pulled back, cutting the ligament under direct vision. After the ligament was fully cut, the instrument was put back in. The edges of the ligament on the radial and ulnar sides were seen and the release was finished. One milliliter of Celestone (a steroid) was injected into the carpal tunnel and washed out. The wound was closed with a running 3‑0 Prolene stitch under the skin. Steri‑strips were applied, and a sterile dressing was put over them. The tourniquet was released. The patient woke up from anesthesia and went to recovery in good condition, having tolerated the procedure well.
